## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**User:**
I'm thinking of downloading the Verus software, but I want to know if I need to pay for it. And what if I'm not satisfied, can I get a refund?

**AI Assistant:**
No, you don't need to pay to download the Verus software. The software is available for free download for different operating systems, along with information on how to verify the downloads. There is no payment or refund process involved. It's completely free to use!

**User:**
That's great! But when I tried to install the Verus software, I got some weird warnings from my antivirus software, Avast and Kaspersky. They said something about a "not-a-virus" warning. What's going on?

**AI Assistant:**
Don't worry, those warnings are not because the Verus software is malicious. They are warnings that you are installing mining software, which may be installed by a third party to exploit your PC. These warnings are false positives, and you can review the resources provided to learn more about them. It's just a precautionary measure from your antivirus software.

**User:**
Okay, that makes sense. But how can I verify the digital signature of the Verus software download to make sure it's legitimate?

**AI Assistant:**
You can verify the digital signature of the Verus software download using the `verus` command itself. Examples of how to do this include `./verus verifyfile` and `./verus verifyhash`. This will ensure that the software you downloaded is authentic and hasn't been tampered with.
Do I need to pay to download the Verus software, and how can I get a refund if I'm not satisfied?

No, you do not need to pay to download the Verus software. The software is available for free download for different operating systems, along with information on how to verify the downloads. There is no payment or refund process involved.

**MacOS:** https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/20ea5429375c6c1a82a27d6de31a480187b97a52eec86aea8f4e8f6789df8e89/detection
**Linux-x86-64:** https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/e881b3fc7d5de1a1e69da3722ac6202bf8c4e4ff8722c9cc2f0f5c587a8a0dd7/detection
**Linux-ARM64:** https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/316a831789cb3e0cc878bab5d847c9b27850ce40feee828bc564373f2b1f59b2/detection
**Windows:** https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/a61fc935bf180690ab7cc34a8da54e36728acfd11a130476be66204ae251f5a6/detectionAvast and Kaspersky may flag the software as "not-a-virus" or "PUP". These are warnings that you are installing mining software, which may be installed by a third party to exploit your PC.

https://www.kaspersky.com/blog/not-a-virus/18015/## Verifying Downloads
A txt file containing the signer, standard sha256 file checksum, and signature, is included for each download. These packages have been signed with the identity "Verus Coin Foundation Releases@".
1) Extract downloaded archive
2) Verify signature for the extracted archive using the extracted text file.
3) Extract archive to desired directory
### CLI examples
**Verifying file directly**
```
./verus verifyfile "Verus Coin Foundation Releases@" "AQRhIwABQSCdvpJmvU7+i9gzPNBtksrPF4IFbPp+F/AfhjIwABQR+53tZoAd2tV1l/XV+Gos9acojPtHrtipWpdpQXKWqS+yRRzXA++Fec/OXT/XJpfa73IUojUhXu7C9t0X2/ldIt" "/Downloads/Verus-CLI-Linux-v0.9.6-x86_64/Verus-CLI-Linux-v0.9.6-x86_64.tar.gz"
```
**Verifying using a checksum**
```
./verus verifyhash "Verus Coin Foundation Releases@" "AQRhIwABQSCdvpJmvU7+i9gzPNBtksrPF4IFbPp+F/AfhjIwABQR+53tZoAd2tV1l/XV+Gos9acojPtHrtipWpdpQXKWqS+yRRzXA++Fec/OXT/XJpfa73IUojUhXu7C9t0X2/ldIt" 2f611ce3d27cadc265f1088508f3dcb2e9262acbcbe8b20bcddc661138303be1
```
What is the purpose of the "not-a-virus" warnings I get from Avast and Kaspersky when I try to install the Verus software?

The "not-a-virus" warnings you get from Avast and Kaspersky are not because the Verus software is malicious. They are warnings that you are installing mining software, which may be installed by a third party to exploit your PC.
